50647: Death Cloud.author: AXER
50647: Death Cloud.text_parsed:
I like Smallpox better. Yeah, it's smaller.


@ Penultimate & Dragek:

Penultimate's suggestion indeed would work! If the game is down to two players, and Penultimate plays this spell which causes his opponent's life to reach zero... it doesn't matter what else the spell requires to happen. Once his/her life reached zero, that opponent loses the game no matter what else is required. The spell's requirements state loss of life BEFORE a Platinum Angel would have to be sacrificed not the other way around. Yes, it does matter.

For example. Take Vampiric Link or Spirit Link. If either is attached to an opponent's creature who deals damage to you, it also causes you to gain that much life... if that creature, however, dealt enough damage to you cause your life to reach 0, you would lose the game immediately and not be able to gain that much life (as it would have also been required.)
50647: Death Cloud.text_posted:
I like [autocard]Smallpox[/autocard] better. Yeah, it's smaller.


@ Penultimate & Dragek:

[b]Penultimate's suggestion indeed would work![/b] If the game is down to two players, and Penultimate plays this spell which causes his opponent's life to reach zero... it doesn't matter what else the spell requires to happen. Once his/her life reached zero, that opponent loses the game no matter what else is required. The spell's requirements state loss of life BEFORE a [autocard]Platinum Angel[/autocard] would have to be sacrificed not the other way around. Yes, it does matter.

For example. Take [autocard]Vampiric Link[/autocard] or [autocard]Spirit Link[/autocard]. If either is attached to an opponent's creature who deals damage to you, it also causes you to gain that much life... if that creature, however, dealt enough damage to you cause your life to reach 0, you would lose the game immediately and not be able to gain that much life (as it [i]would have[/i] also been required.)

50647: Death Cloud.author: mykatdied
50647: Death Cloud.text_parsed: If this card works such as pox then I'm fairly certain the platinum angel would save you. Pox allows for discarding a creature which is then put on to The battlefield to count towards the number of creatures to sacrifice. The effects of the card do happen one at a time and if this killed your opponent before the discard and before the sacrifice then the game would end when your opponent's life became 0, before you discard, before you sacrifice ending the sequence of events with a game win.

The effects of the card do happen one at a time and if this killed your opponent before the discard and before the sacrifice then the game would end when your opponent's life became 0, before you discard, before you sacrifice ending the sequence of events with a game win.

50647: Death Cloud.author: blurrymadness
50647: Death Cloud.text_parsed:
Difficult to use. You want to be in a position to properly own others when all is said and done and to do so you'll need to have stuff that recurs from the graveyard or be in a stronger position *in some way* than your opponents.

So:
-if you have more creatures, make everyone sac creatures until you have the maximum you can have left on an empty battlefield
-if you have several more lands, reset the board except for some of your lands
-if you have several more cards, reset the board enough so you retain card advantage


Coolest things have been mentioned already; it doesn't effect enchants or artifacts, you can utilize this to set up a board position that relies on these other permanents for mana, for destroying creatures, for animating, or what have you; then nuke everything else.

50929: Last Word.author: scumbling1
50929: Last Word.text_parsed:
EDIT - GrimjawxRules: If a spell is still on the stack, it is still a legal target for other spells and abilities. If a player tries to counter your spell with Last Word, he must pass priority after doing so. You then have the opportunity to add additional instant-speed spells / abilities to the stack, like just going back and countering what you want a second time. Until both players pass priority without doing something, the stack is frozen in time, and nothing plays out.

I have to say that I appreciate you actually wanting to have a discussion about it, though. It's a lot more commendable than the six trolls who can't stand not knowing the rules (and consequently downrated my original post). I thought we were here to talk about cards, rather than hide behind an anonymous rating system.

Also, it's pretty funny that the "cum" from my username gets censored. It clearly wasn't inappropriate when I was signing up my account, but the filter can't seem to comprehend that now.

50929: Last Word.author: DarthParallax
50929: Last Word.text_parsed:
4 stars on the nose is a good rating.

It's a hard counter. Hard counters are good. It's a tricky counter. That's very fine. Yes, it's really obvious that Wizards knows there are ways to play around it- other wise it would cost 3UU, or 3UUU, or XUU where X is the converted mana cost of the spell you're countering. Or something like that.

This costs the same as plain-countering a spell and drawing a card, and I'd say that it's nearly equal value. The Mythic rarity also improves this card a lot, since it isn't really quite worth the top rarity level, and yet I can hardly imagine this being a common spell to learn. It's quite specialized, and difficult to learn I bet. It's certainly useful, it just doesn't do as much as it implies.

What it does, is trigger an arms race of rules-savvyness, increasing the overall power of blue mages searching to find the True Counter-Breaker. Along the way, whether they find what they're looking for or not, everyone gets better at the game. In that sense, it is a very powerful spell, not because of what it does directly, but because of what it caused players who saw it to do.

50929: Last Word.author: djflo
50929: Last Word.text_parsed:
This is a good defensive counter, but in terms of countering other people's counters it's hardly the "last word". While you can counter the opponent's first counter , if they can cast others simply targeting the original spell you'll lose the counter war.

A counterspell with split second would be the last word (except for that pesky Willbender).

This card would have seen play in the counter heavy environments of the past, probably as sideboard for control mirrors. These days it could be {1}{U}{U} I think.

50929: Last Word.author: redwinedrummer
50929: Last Word.text_parsed:
This won't really win counter wars as the original spell can be targeted as other members have already pointed out. What this can do, however is to prevent counter wars during your opponent's turn.

If your opponent casts a key card and has countermagic in hand to defend it, playing this immediately will definitely shoot down the spell without offering your opponent a chance to counter back. And even if you succeeded in stopping his spell, you still haven't fished out his countermagic which in turn he can still use to stop your key cards.

Best played on your opponent's turn, not yours.

50943: Arcbound Ravager.author: Mode
50943: Arcbound Ravager.text_parsed:
(from 12/31/2008:) it would maybe even not have been that broken if this card wasn't released in Mirrodin Block along with artifact lands like Seat of the Synod and affinity cards like Frogmite.

another thing, why did The Grand Creature Type Update not assign all arcbound creatures the subtype "Construct"? they look a lot like this to me, and at least the Arcbound Worker has obtained that type as well. at any rate they all have something significant in common. and if they aren't constructs, wouldn't it be worth considering to give them the new creature type "Arcbound" instead?

Edit: yeah stygimoloch, Disciple of the Vault was definitely the second tech card that made Ravager Affinity that powerful. on the other hand, if it hadn't been for a mana base of artifact lands and further free artifact cards there wouldn't have been such an impact after all. but you're right, his trigger is still very powerful for a one-drop even when disregarding these conditions.

How much more should this cost? 1. Yeah. 1. This card's pretty good.

51054: Memnarch.author: Mode
51054: Memnarch.text_parsed:
Well you could use Power Artifact (or even Heartstone) to reduce the cost, in the former case to to take any permanent or to take control of any artifact.
Another more expensive, yet block-constructed option which Mattmedia already mentioned is Mycosynth Lattice, which can be used to skip the first ability and immediately take over anything with the second one (without having to worry about blue mana). Neurok Transmuter might find use for reducing the convertion cost to as well, yet is restricted to creatures. An upside from him is that you can also remove the creature's artifact type the same way, which might be useful in case your opponent tries to shatter some stuff, including Memnarch itself.

Another great thing about Memnarch is that he has a decent 4/5 body and does not require to tap for any of his abilities, which makes him useful for combat as well, provided you can ensure that he won't die there.
He's also one of view high-costed Wizards, which in addition iss an appealing tribal type.
Plus, as opposed to Aladdin for example, you'll keep control of the permanents even if Memnarch leaves play.

Being the main antagonist in the Mirrodin block gives him also a great flavor, which is further fortified by the juicy flavor text and Carl Critchlow's awesome artwork. I mean look at his brain, he's got by far the biggest one on that planet and on top of this most parts of his body consist of metal, there's almost no flesh left.
By the way, another lore thing: Did you know Memnarch was created by Karn from cursed components of the Mirari? After getting corrupted by black oil he later decided to rename "Argentum" to the more known land "Mirrodin" in reference to the Mirari, that is him. And later in the story there's even one crucial moment that even justifies his abilities as printed on the card.

51054: Memnarch.author: Malnourished_Student
51054: Memnarch.text_parsed:
I've built a surprisingly successful deck using 3 Memnarch; 16 Islands, 4 Cloudpost and 4 Guilded Lotus for the mana-base. I use 8 Counterspells of 2 different sorts, and 4 Boomerang for some disruption, giving me the time to get Memnarch out. To keep myself alive from the creatures that get through, I use Spire Golems.
I used to have a couple of Skeleton Shards to bring the various dead creatures back from the graveyard, however I swapped them out after people started exiling Memnarch instead of just killing him. I replaced them and another card with a few Diplomatic Immunity, which covered all I required (make him untargettable, and not be easily removed itself!). I'm testing it tonight.

51055: Slobad, Goblin Tinkerer.author: Leshrac_Nightwalker
51055: Slobad, Goblin Tinkerer.text_parsed:
Hey hey, a legendary goblin! Here we see Slobad performing some much-needed repairs on Bosh, Iron Golem (see here for a close-up face comparison).

In the story, he gave up his chance to ascend to Planeswalker status in order to bring Glissa Sunseeker back to life. I was really disappointed when I read the lore for the Scars block and WotC Creative only gave cursory mention of his demise, saying that he "fell" to other attacking goblins to cover Glissa's retreat back into the core.

As for the card itself, it's an interesting ability. This was the first set to feature indestructibility, and until fairly recently there weren't a lot of other ways to grant it to individual permanents. You can use him in an artifact-heavy deck to cut your Shatterstorm losses in half, for a fraction of the cost of Darksteel Forge - and this is only the tip of the iceberg.
51055: Slobad, Goblin Tinkerer.text_posted:
Hey hey, a legendary goblin!  Here we see Slobad performing some much-needed repairs on [autocard]Bosh, Iron Golem[/autocard] (see [autocard multiverseid="182269"]here[/autocard] for a close-up face comparison).  

In the story, he gave up his chance to ascend to Planeswalker status in order to bring [autocard]Glissa Sunseeker[/autocard] back to life.  I was really disappointed when I read the lore for the Scars block and WotC Creative only gave cursory mention of his demise, saying that he "fell" to other attacking goblins to cover Glissa's retreat back into the core.  

As for the card itself, it's an interesting ability.  This was the first set to feature indestructibility, and until fairly recently there weren't a lot of other ways to grant it to individual permanents.  You can use him in an artifact-heavy deck to cut your [autocard]Shatterstorm[/autocard] losses in half, for a fraction of the cost of [autocard]Darksteel Forge[/autocard] - and this is only the tip of the iceberg.

51070: Geth's Grimoire.author: Mode
51070: Geth's Grimoire.text_parsed:
Really useful. With the right shenanigans this nets an awesome card advantage.
Anvil of Borgadan, Delirium Skeins or Cunning Lethemancer for instance works great with this in a discard deck with Megrim or Liliana's Caress.

When combined with Words of Waste, your opponent won't be able to keep any cards on hand, and if you have the possibility to draw on his/her turn (e.g. with Mind's Eye). this will even create a lockdown.

It would be awesome of it wasn't discard, but put cards from the top of their library. I know that would be extremely OP in a mill deck, but it would make a draw strategy with Jace's Erasure. Essentially, whoever has the most cards left in their deck would win.

But still, this card is okay, I mean it isn't 5/5 because it doesn't work that well for milling, but you can still combo this with other cards like Jace's Erasure (They discard a card, you draw a card, they mill a card from their library). You can add Bloodchief Ascension and have the game in the bag.

51070: Geth's Grimoire.author: Salient
51070: Geth's Grimoire.text_parsed:
Windfall or Winds of Change for the whoomph of it.

This + Words of Waste is a soft lock for per turn. On their turn, pay to replace the card you'd draw from Grimoire with a discard. On your turn, pay to replace your draw-step draw with a discard. They draw one, discard two, and thus can't keep up. Once they're down to an empty hand, draw during your draw step normally, and keep spending the on their turn. When you can, play Nether Void to ensure they can't play any instants they draw.

Use with something like Plague Boiler to wipe stuff already on the battlefield.
51070: Geth's Grimoire.text_posted:
[autocard]Windfall[/autocard] or [autocard]Winds of Change[/autocard] for the whoomph of it.

This + [autocard]Words of Waste[/autocard] is a soft lock for [2] per turn. On their turn, pay [1] to replace the card you'd draw from Grimoire with a discard. On your turn, pay [1] to replace your draw-step draw with a discard. They draw one, discard two, and thus can't keep up. Once they're down to an empty hand, draw during your draw step normally, and keep spending the [1] on their turn. When you can, play [autocard]Nether Void[/autocard] to ensure they can't play any instants they draw.

Use with something like [autocard]Plague Boiler[/autocard] to wipe stuff already on the battlefield.

51074: Heartseeker.author: Artscrafter
51074: Heartseeker.text_parsed:
Speaking of the casual table, Brass Squire turns this into a much more viable kill engine, and curves well into a surprise play. (Turn 2 creature, turn 3 squire, turn 4 play this, equip it to the turn 2 creature and kill something.)

Via the "colorless destruction" comment: Two important points here. First is that there are no restrictions on the effect (except of course for shroud/indestructible/protection from the attached creature) and second, it can go in any deck (blue or green can get a destroy engine.)

I appreciate that the crummy original cards like wooden sphere were upgraded to be less awful and better aesthetically, but these cards are still bait for new players to overvalue, which isn't exactly a design decision I agree with.
